definition: Su Manshu (1884-1918), Chinese writer, journalist, Buddhist monk, participant in the revolutionary movement
old variant of 蘇|苏[su1]
surname Su/abbr. for Soviet Union 蘇維埃|苏维埃 or 蘇聯|苏联/abbr. for Jiangsu province 江蘇|江苏/abbr. for Suzhou city 蘇州|苏州
see 囉囌|啰苏[luo1 su1]
variant of 蘇|苏[su1]/to revive
Perilla frutescens (Chinese basil or wild red basil)/place name/to revive/used as phonetic in transliteration
handsome/large/long
different/unique/special/very/(classical) to behead/to die/to cut off/to separate/to surpass

sentences.english: In the final analysis, it was the cultural background of Su Manshu's age that engendered his poems.
sentences.chinese: 归根到底，这是由苏曼殊所处的时代文化背景决定的。

sentences.english: In the final analysis, it was the cultural background of Su Manshu's…
sentences.chinese: 归根到底，这是由苏曼殊所处的时代文化背景决定的。

definition: Zhang Taiyan (1869-1936), scholar, journalist, revolutionary and leading intellectual around the time of the Xinhai revolution
Yu Dafu (1896-1945), poet and novelist
Hu Shi (1891-1962), original proponent of writing in colloquial Chinese 白話文|白话文[bai2 hua4 wen2]
Lu Xun (1881-1936), one of the earliest and best-known modern Chinese writers
Xu Zhimo (1897-1931), writer and poet
Liu Shipei (1884-1919), Chinese anarchist and revolutionary activist

Zhou Zuoren (1885-1967), brother of Lu Xun 魯迅|鲁迅, academic in Japanese and Greek studies, briefly imprisoned after the war as Japanese collaborator, persecuted and died of unknown causes during the Cultural Revolution
Huang Zunxian (1848-1905), Qing dynasty poet and diplomat, author of A Record of Japan 日本國誌|日本国志[Ri4 ben3 Guo2 zhi4], an extended analysis of Meiji Japan
Guo Moruo (1892-1978), writer, communist party intellectual and cultural apparatchik
Kang Youwei (1858-1927), Confucian intellectual, educator and would-be reformer, main leader of the failed reform movement of 1898
Lin Shu (1852-1924), writer and influential translator and adaptor of vast swathes of Western literature into Classical Chinese
Zhou Shoujuan (1895-1968), writer, translator and art collector in Suzhou, a victim of the Cultural Revolution
Qiu Jin (1875-1907), famous female martyr of the anti-Qing revolution, the subject of several books and films
Chen Duxiu (1879-1942), co-founder of the Chinese Communist Party in 1921
Cai Yuanpei (1868-1940), liberal educationalist, studied in Germany, president of Peking University 1917-19, minister of education for Guomindang
Xiao Hong (1911-1942), prominent woman writer, originally from Heilongjiang
